Metadata.title: Lucie Berkovitch
Metadata.description: Personal website of Lucie Berkovitch, psychiatrist and researcher specializing in psychedelics for mental health treatment

hero.intro: I am <name>Lucie Berkovitch</name>, French psychiatrist and researcher specializing in the use of <specialty>psychedelics in psychiatry</specialty>. My work focuses on understanding the mechanisms of action of these substances and how they could be implemented effectively and safely in public hospitals to help people with psychiatric conditions.
hero.description: I am currently part of the <institute>Neuromodulation Institute</institute> at <hospital>Hôpital Sainte-Anne</hospital> in Paris, where I am responsible for an axis of care and research on psychedelics. We are conducting several clinical trials on the therapeutic potential of psychedelics, as well as fundamental studies. My research is part of a growing body of evidence suggesting the effectiveness of these substances in psychiatry, particularly for treating depression, anxiety, and addiction.

featured.title: Featured publications
featured.subtitle: A selection of my most relevant and notable works.

pub1.description: This review examines how schizophrenia disrupts the neural mechanisms underlying conscious perception. We synthesize evidence showing that patients with schizophrenia exhibit impaired access to conscious awareness, with altered attentional amplification and reduced stability of conscious representations.

pub2.description: This study reveals that antidepressant medication and placebo produce similar patterns of symptom improvement in depression, yet through fundamentally different neural mechanisms. Using advanced neuroimaging and computational modeling, we demonstrate that clinical outcomes can converge despite divergent brain activity patterns.

pub3.description: This experimental study investigates how ketamine affects conscious awareness in healthy volunteers. We demonstrate that ketamine-induced alterations in consciousness correlate with the emergence of psychotic-like symptoms, providing a controlled model to understand the neural basis of both psychedelic experiences and psychosis-related phenomena.
